subject: Re: [junit] All Methods Public

messageBody:
Ole,

It has been proposed in the past--I can't seem to find it on Google,
but I have a memory of Ron Jeffries quoting someone else who had done
a small experiment of making all methods public and still having a
sensible API, and had liked the results.

I myself am not tempted to go to this extreme. Private methods
generally mean that I have several abstraction layers living within
the same class. I'm not bothered by this in principle, until I find
the "hidden" abstraction layer troublesome or interesting enough that
I'm tempted to test it directly, in which case I take the time to
think about the name and interface of that hidden abstraction layer,
and expose it as a class.

David Saff

On 2/12/07, Ole Ersoy <ole_ersoy@...> wrote:
> Hi Guys,
>
> Would it be a good idea to always use all public
> methods...?
>
> In the context of a convention where there is a
> "MainClass" and a "MainClassHelper" that has public
> methods used to help the MainClass.
>
> Users of MainClassHelper (The collaborator should
> really be MainClass only) know that this class exists
> mainly for the purpose of helping MainClass, and all
> the methods are public, so that they can be easily
> unit tested.
>
> Otherwise they would be private or protected members
> of MainClass.
>
> So MainClassHelper can really be thought of as a
> utility library that is specific to MainClass...
>
> Anyone know if there are security risks to this,
> beside API risks?
>
> Thanks,
> - Ole
